bestBHT.bht: Paul addresses the issue of regarding certain days as holy, emphasizing the principle of freedom in non-essential matters. Some believe they are bound by God to observe these days and others feel free to eat any type of food. Those who regard the day as holy do so unto the Lord, giving thanks for their meal, while those who abstain from eating also regard it unto the Lord, giving thanks for their herbs. Paul pleads for liberty and reminds believers that they are accountable to the Lord in their actions.

Henry Alford: The words in brackets do not occur in most of our early authorities. They were probably omitted from the similar ending of both clauses in the original having misled some early copyists, and the eye having passed from one to the other (a very usual mistake); but perhaps."
It may have been intentionally done, after the observation of the Lord’s Day came to be regarded as binding.
The 'saying grace' of the abstainer, was over his 'dinner of herbs.' The Lord throughout the verse is CHRIST.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: He that regardeth the day, regardeth it to the Lord—the Lord CHRIST, as before."
The one gave thanks to God for the flesh which the other scrupled to use; the other did the same for the herbs to which, for conscience' sake, he restricted himself."
Certainly it could not, if the sabbath were merely one of the Jewish festival days; but it will not do to take this for granted merely because it was observed under the Mosaic economy.
Albert Barnes: He that regardeth it as 'holy,' or as set apart to the service of God. He believes that he is 'required' by God to keep it, that is, that the laws of Moses in regard to such days are binding on him.
He eats to the Lord because he believes that God does not forbid it; and because he desires, in doing it, to glorify God.
He abstains from eating because he believes that God requires him to do it, and with a desire to obey and honor him.
Marvin Vincent: He that regardeth not - doth not regard it. Omit.
John Calvin: He who regarded days committed no sin; for nothing but good can be accepted by God.
He dared not to do anything with a doubtful conscience.
Eating is impure, and abstinence is impure, without thanksgiving.
Philip Schaff: He that regardeth the day, regardeth it unto the Lord.
The Lord’s day has other claims than those of Jewish or Christian festivals.
The man who ate without scruple ate as a Christian man, 'unto the Lord,' while on the other hand he who scrupulously abstained also regarded himself as abstaining from the same Christian motive.
Archibald T. Robertson: Regardeth (φρονε). 'Thinks of,' 'esteems,' 'observes,' 'puts his mind on'... it is not genuine.
He eats unto the Lord, he eats not unto the Lord. Paul's principle of freedom in non-essentials is most important.
John Gill: Whether he is right or wrong, it is to the Lord he does it, and to his own master he stands or falls.
To regard the days of the feast of tabernacles, is tacitly to say, that the Word has not tabernacled among us.

The man that is strong in faith, and is fully persuaded by the Lord Jesus that all distinction of meats, as of days, is ceased, eats any thing, and every sort of food, that comes in his way, without making any difference.
John Wesley: Regardeth it to the Lord — That is, out of a principle of conscience toward God.
To the Lord he doth not regard it — He also acts from a principle of conscience.
He that eateth not — Flesh. Giveth God thanks — For his herbs.

bhtAttempts.bht: Some people may regard certain days as holy, feeling obligated by God to observe them, while others believe that they are not bound by such laws and are therefore free to eat any type of food. The one who regards the day as holy does so unto the Lord, giving thanks for the flesh they eat, while the one who abstains from eating does so also unto the Lord, giving thanks for their herbs. Paul emphasizes the principle of freedom in non-essential matters and pleads for liberty. Whatever one's convictions may be, they are accountable to the Lord and should act in accordance with their conscience. Ultimately, to the Lord they do it and to their own master they stand or fall.
